Young Jean Grey discovers her telepathy is emerging early and reads everyone's minds, learning devastating future truths (#8). Mystique, Sabretooth, and Lady Mastermind begin a criminal spree using the chaos of two teams of X-Men (#9-10). Marquez's art is gorgeous.
connection_notes: Follows: All-New X-Men Vol. 1. Leads to: All-New X-Men Vol. 3 (Battle of the Atom). Parallel: Uncanny X-Men by Bendis.

title: Avengers & X-Men: Axis
synopsis: Red Skull, empowered by Xavier's brain, becomes Red Onslaught and attacks Genosha (#1-3). Heroes and villains team up to stop him, but a spell by Scarlet Witch and Doctor Doom goes wrong and inverts everyone's morality (#4). Evil Avengers and heroic villains clash across the globe (#5-8). The inversion is mostly reversed (#9), but some changes stick — notably Sabretooth stays heroic and Iron Man stays 'superior.'
connection_notes: Follows: Uncanny Avengers by Remender. Ties into: Magneto, Superior Iron Man, Uncanny X-Men. Leads to: Secret Wars (2015).

title: Avengers: Time Runs Out Complete Collection
synopsis: Eight months in the future, the Avengers have fractured. Steve Rogers hunts the Illuminati for their incursion crimes. Tony Stark is broken. Namor allies with Thanos' Cabal to destroy colliding Earths. The final incursion approaches — Earth-616 vs. Earth-1610 (Ultimate Universe). Every chess piece Hickman placed over years converges (#44). Reed Richards can't save everything. The multiverse dies.
connection_notes: Prerequisite for: Secret Wars (2015). Follows: Avengers/New Avengers by Hickman. The final act before the multiverse ends.

title: FF by Matt Fraction: The Complete Collection
synopsis: Two parallel series. Fantastic Four: the Richards family takes a cosmic road trip through time and space to fix Reed's genetic deterioration (#1-16, Bagley art). FF: She-Hulk, Medusa, Ms. Thing, and Ant-Man (Scott Lang) substitute as the Future Foundation (#1-16, Allred art). The FF side is the standout — Allred's pop art style and Scott Lang's single-dad energy create a warm, funny, and inventive book.
connection_notes: Follows: FF by Hickman. Parallel: Avengers by Hickman. Leads to: Fantastic Four in Secret Wars.

title: Daredevil by Mark Waid Vol. 2
synopsis: Matt Murdock discovers a massive criminal conspiracy — the Megacrime Omega Drive containing secrets of every major crime organization (#8-10). He and Black Cat partner to keep the drive from A.I.M., Hydra, and the Secret Empire simultaneously. The iconic snowstorm issue (#7) shows Matt navigating a blizzard by sound. Rivera's radar-sense splash pages define the run's visual innovation.
connection_notes: Follows: Daredevil by Waid Vol. 1. Leads to: Daredevil by Waid Vol. 3, then the San Francisco relocation.

title: Moon Knight by Ellis & Shalvey Vol. 2: Dead Will Rise
synopsis: After Ellis's departure, Brian Wood continues with Smallwood's innovative layouts. Marc Spector investigates a mind-control conspiracy in New York while grappling with Khonshu's demands (#7-12). Smallwood uses split-page designs and color-coded identities — white for Moon Knight, black for Marc Spector — to visualize mental illness. The Dr. Elisa Warsame sessions frame each issue. Less standalone than Ellis, but visually groundbreaking.
connection_notes: Follows: Moon Knight by Ellis. Leads to: Moon Knight by Lemire. Smallwood's visual innovations carry forward.

title: She-Hulk by Charles Soule: The Complete Collection
synopsis: Jennifer Walters opens her own law practice with paralegal Angie Huang (and her mysterious monkey) and investigator Patsy Walker. She takes on a wrongful death case involving Captain America (#1-4), defends Doom's son in a custody battle, and discovers the Blue File — a case so dangerous its participants had their memories erased (#8-12). Soule (an actual lawyer) makes legal drama genuinely compelling. Pulido's clean, European-influenced art is distinctive.
connection_notes: Parallel: Daredevil by Waid (legal genre). Self-contained. Leads to: A-Force in Secret Wars. She-Hulk's legal focus continues in later series.

title: Inhuman by Charles Soule: The Complete Collection
synopsis: After Infinity, Black Bolt detonates the Terrigen Bomb over New York, creating NuHumans worldwide. Medusa leads the Inhumans without Black Bolt. New Inhumans emerge: Inferno, Flint, Naja, and Reader (#1-7). Lash, a fundamentalist Inhuman, judges which NuHumans deserve their powers and kills those he deems unworthy (#8-11). The Unspoken returns for vengeance (#12-14). Sets up the Inhumans' expansion across the Marvel line.
connection_notes: Follows: Infinity by Hickman (Terrigen Bomb). Leads to: Uncanny Inhumans, then Inhumans vs. X-Men. Parallel: Ms. Marvel (NuHuman).

title: Silver Surfer by Slott & Allred Vol. 2: Worlds Apart
synopsis: The Surfer and Dawn Greenwood's cosmic road trip continues. They visit a planet where everyone is a perfect duplicate of someone from Earth (#6-7). The Surfer faces his history as Galactus' herald when Dawn learns the full truth about the worlds he helped destroy (#8-9). The Secret Wars tie-in (#10) sees them on Battleworld. Allred's pop art perfectly captures the whimsy and emotional depth.
connection_notes: Follows: Silver Surfer by Slott Vol. 1. Leads to: Silver Surfer post-Secret Wars continuation. Parallel: Guardians of the Galaxy.

title: Doctor Strange by Aaron Vol. 2: The Last Days of Magic
synopsis: The Empirikul — a science-worshipping army led by the Imperator — invades Earth and systematically destroys all magic (#6-10). Every magical artifact, every spell, every mystical being is targeted. Strange must fight without his powers, relying on an axe and sheer determination. The cost of magic is revealed: Strange has been secretly absorbing mystical pain for years (#11-12). Bachalo's chaotic art perfectly suits the magical apocalypse.
connection_notes: Follows: Doctor Strange by Aaron Vol. 1. Leads to: Doctor Strange Vol. 3. Parallel: Scarlet Witch by Robinson.

title: Black Panther by Coates Vol. 2: A Nation Under Our Feet Book 2
synopsis: The revolution deepens. Zenzi's psychic manipulation turns more Wakandans against T'Challa. The Midnight Angels (Aneka and Ayo) build their Jabari-Lands liberation movement (#5-6). Changamire the philosopher provides intellectual fuel for the rebellion. Shuri exists in a spiritual plane, gathering the nation's ancestral memories (#7-8). Coates deconstructs the idea of benevolent monarchy with literary ambition. The political philosophy is dense and rewarding.
connection_notes: Follows: Black Panther by Coates Vol. 1. Leads to: A Nation Under Our Feet Book 3. Parallel: Ultimates by Ewing.

title: The Mighty Thor by Aaron Vol. 2: Lords of Midgard
synopsis: Jane Foster faces the corporate machinations of Dario Agger and Roxxon, who has merged with dark elves from Alfheim (#6-8). The Silver Samurai and Exterminatrix attack. Agger literally bulldozes Alfheim for its resources. Meanwhile, Jane's cancer worsens — every time she transforms into Thor, the chemotherapy is purged from her body (#9-11). The War Thor arc hints at the Mangog's return. Dauterman's art is a career best.
connection_notes: Follows: Mighty Thor Vol. 1. Leads to: Mighty Thor Vol. 3 (Death of the Mighty Thor). Part of Aaron's complete Thor saga.

title: Invincible Iron Man: Ironheart — The Complete Collection
synopsis: Riri Williams, a 15-year-old MIT engineering prodigy, reverse-engineers her own Iron Man suit. After Tony Stark falls in Civil War II, an A.I. copy of Tony guides Riri as Ironheart (#1-3). She faces Techno Golem and her mother's concerns about a teenager being a superhero (#4-7). Tomoe and the Biohack Ninjas threaten Chicago (#8-11). Bendis writes Riri as brilliant but realistically inexperienced.
connection_notes: Follows: Civil War II. Parallel: Infamous Iron Man (Doom), Spider-Man (Miles Morales). Leads to: Champions, Ironheart solo.

title: Champions by Waid Vol. 2: The Freelancer Lifestyle
synopsis: The Champions — Ms. Marvel, Miles Morales, Nova, Viv Vision, Amadeus Cho, and Cyclops — tackle real-world issues. They face human trafficking (#7-8), a town's water supply poisoned by corporate negligence (#9-10), and the Secret Empire tie-in where the team resists Hydra Captain America (#11-12). Waid writes the team as idealistic teens genuinely trying to make a difference without adult cynicism.
connection_notes: Follows: Champions Vol. 1. Ties into: Secret Empire. Leads to: Champions by Zub. Parallel: Avengers (2016).

title: Occupy Avengers: Taking Back Justice
synopsis: Depowered Hawkeye (Clint Barton), guilt-ridden after killing Bruce Banner in Civil War II, travels America fighting for communities ignored by the system. He starts in Sweet Springs, Iowa, where a Native American reservation has been poisoned (#1-4). Red Wolf, Tilda Johnson (Nightshade), and Wheels Wolinski join. Walker uses the road trip format to address water rights, neglected communities, and grassroots heroism (#5-9).
connection_notes: Follows: Civil War II. Parallel: Champions. Ties into: Secret Empire. Hawkeye's guilt from killing Banner drives the series.

title: U.S.Avengers: American Intelligence Mechanics
synopsis: Roberto Da Costa transforms A.I.M. into American Intelligence Mechanics and leads the U.S.Avengers: Red Hulk (General Maverick), Squirrel Girl, Enigma (Aikku Jokinen), Iron Patriot (Toni Ho), Pod, and Cannonball. The Golden Skull attacks (#1-3). Each issue's cover features a different state. The Secret Empire arc (#5-10) traps Roberto and Cannonball on another planet while Hydra takes over. Ewing's signature deep-cut continuity love is evident.
connection_notes: Follows: New Avengers by Ewing. Ties into: Secret Empire. Parallel: Avengers (2016). Ewing's love letter to obscure Marvel lore.

title: New Avengers (2015) by Ewing: A.I.M.
synopsis: Sunspot buys A.I.M. and tries to reform it into a force for good. His New Avengers team — Wiccan, Hulkling, Squirrel Girl, White Tiger, Power Man, Songbird, and Pod — operates out of A.I.M. Island. They face the Maker (evil Reed Richards from the Ultimate Universe), W.H.I.S.P.E.R., and S.H.I.E.L.D.'s distrust (#1-6). Ewing juggles a huge cast with humor and heart.
connection_notes: Follows: Avengers World, Secret Wars. Leads to: U.S.Avengers. Parallel: Ultimates by Ewing. Part of Ewing's connected Marvel narrative.

title: Unbeatable Squirrel Girl Omnibus
synopsis: Doreen Green starts college at Empire State University while secretly being the unbeatable Squirrel Girl. She defeats Galactus by befriending him (#4), fights Doctor Doom with computer science (#10), and time-travels with her roommate Nancy (#5). North brings comedic brilliance and genuine computer science knowledge. The bottom-of-page alt text jokes are a signature. Henderson's expressive art perfectly suits the irreverent tone. The run that proved comedy comics can thrive.
connection_notes: Self-contained. Cameos across the Marvel line. Parallel: Gwenpool, Ms. Marvel. Doreen appears in New Avengers by Ewing.

title: Gwenpool, the Unbelievable Vol. 2: Head of M.O.D.O.K.
synopsis: Gwen Poole, a girl from our world trapped in the Marvel Universe, becomes leader of a M.O.D.O.K. cell (#6-8). Her knowledge of comics as a reader gives her meta-awareness of plot armor and character importance. She manipulates genre conventions while genuinely caring about 'fictional' people (#9-10). Gurihiru's adorable art belies surprisingly dark themes about what happens to forgotten characters.
connection_notes: Follows: Gwenpool Vol. 1. Leads to: Gwenpool Vol. 3. Self-contained meta-comedy. Parallel: Squirrel Girl.

title: Moon Girl and Devil Dinosaur: The Complete Collection Vol. 1
synopsis: Lunella Lafayette, a 9-year-old Inhuman genius in the Lower East Side, befriends Devil Dinosaur when a Kree device pulls him through time (#1-4). She's confirmed as the smartest person in the Marvel Universe — smarter than Reed Richards, Amadeus Cho, and T'Challa (#8-12). The Cosmic Cooties arc (#13-18) sees her switching bodies with Devil Dinosaur. Bustos' vibrant art and the kid-friendly tone make this an all-ages gem.
connection_notes: Parallel: Ms. Marvel, Champions. Self-contained. Lunella later appears in Champions and various team-ups.

title: Power Man and Iron Fist by David Walker
synopsis: Luke Cage and Danny Rand reunite for old-school Harlem adventures. Tombstone wants the Supersoul Stone (#1-5), a mystical artifact that grants control over anyone who touches it. Jessica Jones disapproves of Luke's return to heroics. Greene's kinetic, hip-hop-influenced art style breathes fresh energy into the classic Heroes for Hire dynamic. Civil War II drives them apart (#6-9) when they land on opposite sides.
connection_notes: Parallel: Jessica Jones, Luke Cage solo. Ties into: Civil War II. Classic Heroes for Hire energy with modern style.

title: Cage!
synopsis: Genndy Tartakovsky (Samurai Jack, Dexter's Laboratory) brings his animation style to a retro Luke Cage adventure. Set in a 1970s blaxploitation aesthetic, Cage fights a horde of villains through a wild night in New York. Minimal dialogue, maximum visual storytelling. Giant splash pages, kinetic action sequences, and Tartakovsky's signature angular character designs make this feel like a lost animated film on paper.
connection_notes: Self-contained. A stylistic showcase. No continuity ties required.

title: Jessica Jones by Bendis: The Complete Collection
synopsis: The Alias team reunites. Jessica appears to betray Luke and the superhero community, but it's a deep cover operation (#1-6). She investigates the aftermath of Civil War II, clients whose lives were ruined by Ulysses' predictions. Maria Hill hires Jessica for off-the-books work (#7-12). The Purple Man returns (#13-18), and Jessica must protect her daughter Danielle from Kilgrave's obsession. Gaydos' noir-drenched art perfectly matches the tone.
connection_notes: Follows: Alias, The Pulse. Parallel: Luke Cage, Defenders. One of Bendis' final Marvel works before his DC move.

title: Luke Cage by David Walker
synopsis: Luke Cage heads to New Orleans to investigate the death of a long-lost friend, Dr. Noah Burstein — the man who gave him his powers. Luke discovers Burstein was running illegal experiments creating new super-powered people (#1-3). A conspiracy involving the Ringmaster and a sinister clinic leads to a confrontation about Luke's own origin and the ethics of human enhancement (#4-5). Walker writes Luke as a thoughtful, community-minded hero.
connection_notes: Parallel: Jessica Jones by Bendis, Power Man and Iron Fist. Self-contained mini-series.

title: Silk by Robbie Thompson: The Complete Collection
synopsis: Cindy Moon, bitten by the same spider as Peter Parker and locked in a bunker for a decade, builds a life as a hero and journalist at the Fact Channel. She searches for her missing family (#1-7) while balancing her Spider-powers. In volume two, she goes undercover for S.H.I.E.L.D. inside Black Cat's criminal empire (#1-7) and faces Mattie Franklin's legacy (#8-12). Lee's manga-influenced art gives Silk a distinctive visual identity.
connection_notes: Follows: Spider-Verse (Silk's debut). Parallel: Amazing Spider-Man, Spider-Woman. Leads to: Silk appearances in Clone Conspiracy.

title: Spider-Man 2099 by Peter David: The Complete Collection Vol. 1
synopsis: Miguel O'Hara is stranded in the present-day Marvel Universe after Spider-Verse, working at Parker Industries. He discovers that events in the present are creating a catastrophic future (#1-5). The Fist of the Spider Society hunts him. Post-Secret Wars, Miguel works to prevent 2099 from becoming a dystopia by fixing the present (#1-8). David returns to his signature character with time-travel plots and corporate espionage.
connection_notes: Follows: Spider-Verse. Parallel: Amazing Spider-Man (Parker Industries era). David created Miguel in 1992's Spider-Man 2099.

title: Web Warriors: Electroverse
synopsis: Spider-heroes from across the multiverse — Spider-UK, Spider-Gwen, Spider-Ham, Spider-Man Noir, Spider-Man India, and Anya Corazon — protect the Web of Life after Spider-Verse. Electro variants threaten every dimension (#1-5). The Battery, a nexus of Electro energy, could collapse the multiverse. Each issue spotlights a different Spider-hero's universe (#6-8). The Web of Life and Destiny mythology deepens.
connection_notes: Follows: Spider-Verse. Parallel: Spider-Gwen, Silk. Leads to: Spider-Geddon concepts.

title: Scarlet Witch by Robinson Vol. 2: World of Witchcraft
synopsis: Wanda's globe-trotting investigation into broken witchcraft continues. She visits Hong Kong (#6, Lotay art), Ireland (#7, Wu art), and Morocco, each issue featuring a different artist matching the location's mood. Wanda meets her biological mother, Natalya Maximoff, revealed as the previous Scarlet Witch (#8-10). Robinson redefines Wanda's magical lineage separate from Magneto. The rotating artist approach makes each issue visually unique.
connection_notes: Follows: Scarlet Witch Vol. 1. Leads to: Scarlet Witch Vol. 3 (full Witches' Road arc). Parallel: Doctor Strange by Aaron.

title: Royals
synopsis: After Inhumans vs. X-Men, the Inhuman Royal Family — Black Bolt, Medusa, Crystal, Gorgon, Swain, and Flint — journey into space to find the Progenitors, the alien race that created the Kree and, by extension, the Inhumans themselves. A framing device set 5,000 years in the future (#1) reveals one of them won't survive. Ewing connects Inhuman mythology to the Celestials and Kree in cosmic scope (#7-12).
connection_notes: Follows: Inhumans vs. X-Men. Parallel: Black Bolt by Ahmed. Leads to: Death of the Inhumans by Donny Cates.

title: Thanos by Jeff Lemire: The Complete Collection
synopsis: Thanos is dying. His son Thane, corrupted by the Phoenix Force, and a death-cult led by the Champion hunt the weakened Titan. Thanos returns to his throne on Titan to prepare for death — but refuses to go quietly (#1-6). Starfox, Nebula, and Tryco Slatterus converge. The final arc (#7-12) pits Thane against his father in a battle where Death herself is the prize. Lemire writes Thanos as terrifyingly sympathetic in his final days.
connection_notes: Leads to: Thanos Wins by Cates (#13-18). Follows: Infinity by Hickman. Parallel: Guardians of the Galaxy.

title: Black Bolt by Saladin Ahmed: The Complete Collection
synopsis: Black Bolt wakes up in an alien prison run by the Jailer, stripped of his powers and voice. He bonds with fellow inmates Absorbing Man, a Skrull named Blinky, a telepathic child, and Raava the Un-Skrulled (#1-6). Ahmed makes the silent king profoundly human through his internal narration. Ward's psychedelic, color-saturated art is unlike anything else at Marvel. The escape and return (#7-12) forces Black Bolt to confront his own tyrannical history.
connection_notes: Parallel: Royals. Leads to: Death of the Inhumans. One of the most artistically ambitious Marvel books of the era.

title: Jean Grey by Dennis Hopeless
synopsis: Time-displaced young Jean Grey senses the Phoenix Force returning and trains to fight it. She seeks mentors across the Marvel Universe — Namor (#2), Psylocke (#3), Rachel Grey (#5), Emma Frost (#6), and Odinson (#7) — each teaching different aspects of power and control. Jean confronts her fear of becoming Dark Phoenix, a destiny she's determined to avoid (#8-11). Hopeless writes a compelling coming-of-age about living in your future self's shadow.
connection_notes: Follows: All-New X-Men. Leads to: Phoenix Resurrection, then X-Men Red. Parallel: All-New Wolverine.

title: Iceman by Sina Grace: The Complete Collection
synopsis: Bobby Drake comes out as gay and navigates dating, family, and being an Omega-level mutant simultaneously. He faces his disapproving parents (#3-4), reconnects with his Champions teammates, and battles the Purifiers targeting LGBTQ+ youth (#6-8). The Daken relationship is explored. Season two (#1-5) addresses the Morlocks, Sinister, and Bobby confronting his emotional walls. Grace writes identity with authenticity and warmth.
connection_notes: Follows: All-New X-Men (coming out scene). Parallel: Jean Grey solo, Generation X. Leads to: Bobby's role in Marauders (Krakoa era).

title: Generation X (2017)
synopsis: Jubilee teaches a class of misfit mutants at the Xavier School — Nature Girl, Eye-Boy, Hindsight, Bling!, Morph, and Quentin Quire. These are the mutants whose powers aren't combat-useful or conventionally attractive. Emplate, Jubilee's old nemesis, returns hunting the students (#5-9). Strain writes the school setting with genuine teen dynamics: awkward friendships, crushes, and the fear of being 'useless' mutants.
connection_notes: Follows: Generation X legacy. Parallel: X-Men Blue, Jean Grey solo. Short-lived but charming school book.

title: Weapon X by Greg Pak: Weapons of Mutant Destruction
synopsis: A new Weapon X program targets mutants for elimination using Adamantium cyborgs. Old Man Logan, Sabretooth, Lady Deathstrike, Warpath, and Domino are hunted individually before uniting (#1-4). The team discovers the program is creating Hulk/Wolverine hybrid weapons. Weapons of Mutant Destruction crossover (#5-9, TAH #19-22) pits the team against Weapon H — a soldier combined with Hulk and Wolverine DNA. Pak delivers high-octane mutant action.
connection_notes: Parallel: Old Man Logan, All-New Wolverine. Leads to: Weapon H solo series. Ties into: broader X-line.

title: Old Man Logan by Jeff Lemire: The Complete Collection
synopsis: The Wolverine from Mark Millar's dystopian future lives in the main Marvel Universe post-Secret Wars. Logan tries to prevent his dark future from happening — he confronts the Reavers (#1-4), Lady Deathstrike, and the Brood. Sorrentino's experimental layouts — double-page spreads with inset panels, color-shifted nightmare sequences — are stunning. The Silent Order arc (#7-8) and return to the Wasteland (#13-15) are highlights. Logan grapples with whether the future can be changed.
connection_notes: Follows: Secret Wars, Old Man Logan mini. Parallel: All-New Wolverine. Leads to: Weapon X, then Dead Man Logan.

title: All-New Wolverine Vol. 2: Civil War II
synopsis: Laura Kinney faces a Civil War II crisis when Ulysses predicts Old Man Logan will murder Gabby (#7-8). Laura must protect her clone-sister while navigating the moral dilemma of preemptive justice. The Wolverines vs. Fin Fang Foom adventure (#9-11) is a lighter palate cleanser where Laura, Gabby, and Jonathan the Wolverine (an actual wolverine) fight a dragon. Issue #12 features Gabby's Christmas adventure. Taylor balances heavy themes with genuine warmth.
connection_notes: Follows: All-New Wolverine Vol. 1. Ties into: Civil War II. Leads to: All-New Wolverine Vol. 3 (Enemy of the State II).

title: Foolkiller by Max Bemis
synopsis: Greg Salinger, the Foolkiller, becomes a therapist for supervillains as part of S.H.I.E.L.D.'s rehabilitation program. His patients include Deadpool-adjacent characters and D-list villains trying to go straight (#1-3). But Salinger's own violent tendencies resurface when a former patient goes on a rampage (#4-5). Bemis explores mental health in the Marvel Universe through a darkly comedic lens. Part of the Marvel NOW! wave of oddball titles.
connection_notes: Parallel: Slapstick, Solo. Part of the Mercs for Money adjacent line. Self-contained dark comedy.

title: Slapstick by Reilly Brown & Fred Van Lente
synopsis: Steve Harmon, a teenager transformed into a living cartoon character, tries to monetize his powers as a social media hero after leaving the Mercs for Money. His cartoon physics mean he can't be killed but also can't feel anything (#1-3). When Bro-Man and Tasky (Taskmaster's apprentice) threaten his hometown, Slapstick must decide if being a joke means he can't be a hero (#4-6). A self-aware comedy about D-list Marvel life.
connection_notes: Parallel: Foolkiller, Solo, Gwenpool. Self-contained comedy mini-series.

title: Solo by Gerry Duggan
synopsis: James Bourne, the teleporting mercenary Solo, impersonates Spider-Man to build street cred and get better-paying mercenary jobs (#1-2). His teleportation powers are degrading, and he seeks a cure from shady sources. S.H.I.E.L.D. and Spider-Man both want answers. Solo discovers a conspiracy involving his old military unit (#3-5). Shaw's gritty art suits the espionage tone. A surprisingly engaging noir take on a forgotten '90s character.
connection_notes: Part of the Mercs for Money orbit. Parallel: Foolkiller, Slapstick. Self-contained.

title: Mosaic by Geoffrey Thorne
synopsis: Morris Sackett, an arrogant NBA superstar, undergoes Terrigenesis and becomes Mosaic — an Inhuman who can possess and absorb the knowledge and skills of anyone he inhabits, but loses his physical body (#1-3). He jumps from person to person learning empathy the hard way. When Brand Corporation targets him, Mosaic must use his possession powers heroically (#4-8). Randolph's electric color work and Thorne's character study of ego loss make this a hidden gem.
connection_notes: Ties into: Inhumans line, IvX. Parallel: Inhuman, Ms. Marvel. Mosaic appears in Inhumans vs. X-Men.

title: America by Gabby Rivera
synopsis: America Chavez, dimension-punching powerhouse and former Young Avenger, enrolls at Sotomayor University — a cosmic college outside normal reality (#1-3). She takes a class on interdimensional leadership while investigating the Midas Corporation and its ties to the Utopian Parallel. America explores her heritage, her mothers' legacy, and her place in the multiverse (#4-12). World War II crossover (#3-4) teams her with Peggy Carter.
connection_notes: Follows: Young Avengers by Gillen, Ultimates by Ewing. Parallel: Champions. America's first solo series.

title: Secret Warriors (2017) by Matthew Rosenberg
synopsis: During Secret Empire, Quake assembles a team of Inhumans and mutants — Ms. Marvel, Karnak, Moon Girl, Devil Dinosaur, and Inferno — to resist Hydra Captain America's regime (#1-5). The team operates underground in the Darkforce-covered Manhattan. After Secret Empire, they face Mr. Sinister's interest in Inhuman genetics and a Darkforce entity (#6-12). Rosenberg writes sharp team dynamics between characters who shouldn't work together but do.
connection_notes: Ties into: Secret Empire. Follows: Inhumans line. Features Ms. Marvel outside her solo. Parallel: Champions resistance.

title: Monsters Unleashed
synopsis: Giant Leviathon monsters invade Earth from space, requiring every Marvel hero to fight building-sized kaiju in cities worldwide. Elsa Bloodstone leads the monster hunting. Kid Kaiju (Kei Kawade), a young Inhuman who can summon monsters by drawing them, is the key — his drawings bring Marvel's classic monsters (Fin Fang Foom, Devil Dinosaur, Orrgo) to life (#1-3). The heroes must use the monsters to fight the Leviathons (#4-5). Big, fun event with rotating artists.
connection_notes: Self-contained event. Leads to: Monsters Unleashed ongoing (Kid Kaiju). Features all major Marvel teams.

title: Venomverse / Venomized
issues_collected: Venomverse #1-5, Venomverse: War Stories #1, Edge of Venomverse #1-5
synopsis: The Poisons, interdimensional predators that permanently bond with and consume symbiote hosts, threaten the multiverse. Eddie Brock (Venom) is pulled into a war across realities alongside Venomized heroes — Venom Wolverine, Venom Captain America, Venom Rocket Raccoon (#1-5). Edge of Venomverse introduces each variant. The concept is pure fan-service: 'what if everyone was Venom?' executed with gleeful excess.
connection_notes: Parallel: Venom by Lee Price, Venom by Cates (soon). Follows: Venom Space Knight. Leads into: Venom by Donny Cates conceptually.

title: Daredevil by Mark Waid Vol. 3: The Devil's Hand
synopsis: Matt Murdock's public identity crisis deepens. Five crime organizations form a mega-syndicate to recover the Omega Drive (#11-13). Samnee takes over art duties permanently and his clean, kinetic style becomes inseparable from the series. The Coyote, a teleportation-powered villain, threatens both Matt and Foggy (#14-15). Waid and Samnee develop a visual shorthand for Matt's radar sense that becomes iconic.
connection_notes: Follows: Daredevil by Waid Vol. 2. Leads to: Daredevil by Waid San Francisco era. Parallel: Superior Spider-Man.

title: Nova (2015) by Sean Ryan
synopsis: Sam Alexander continues his Nova career while dealing with high school and his father Jesse's disappearance. Sam encounters Carnage in space (#1-3), teams with the New Warriors, and searches for his father across the galaxy (#7-11). The series explores the cost of being a teenage cosmic hero: grades slip, friendships suffer, and Sam's mother struggles as a single parent. The emotional core grounds the cosmic action.
connection_notes: Follows: Nova by Loeb. Leads to: Nova (2016), then Champions. Parallel: Ms. Marvel, Spider-Man (Miles).

title: Mighty Avengers by Al Ewing: No Single Hero
issues_collected: Mighty Avengers (2013) #1-14, Captain America and the Mighty Avengers #1-9
synopsis: Luke Cage assembles a community-based Avengers team during Infinity: Spectrum, White Tiger, Power Man (Victor Alvarez), Spider-Man (Superior), Blue Marvel, She-Hulk, and Falcon (#1-6). Blue Marvel and Spectrum's dynamic becomes central. The team battles the Deathwalkers, Jason Quantrell's Cortex Inc., and Shuma-Gorath (#7-14). Post-Axis, the team opposes Superior Iron Man (#CA&MA #1-9). Ewing plants seeds for Ultimates and his broader Marvel cosmology.
connection_notes: Follows: New Avengers by Bendis. Leads to: Ultimates by Ewing, New Avengers by Ewing. Ewing's first major Avengers work.

title: Ms. Marvel by G. Willow Wilson Vol. 3: Crushed
synopsis: Kamala navigates her first crush on the new Inhuman Kamran (#12-15), who shares her cultural background and powers — but works for Lineage, who wants to control NuHumans. The Secret Wars Last Days arc (#16-18) sees Kamala facing the end of the world alongside her brother Aamir. Wilson writes teenage romance and the apocalypse with equal emotional honesty. Includes the Spider-Man team-up from ASM where Kamala meets her hero.
connection_notes: Follows: Ms. Marvel Vol. 2. Leads to: Ms. Marvel post-Secret Wars. Ties into: Inhuman/Inhumanity line, Secret Wars.

title: Inhumans Prime / Inhumans vs. X-Men
synopsis: The Terrigen Cloud circling Earth is killing mutants. Emma Frost leads the X-Men to war against the Inhumans to destroy it. Medusa, Black Bolt, Karnak, and the Royal Family defend the cloud that creates their people (#0-3). Twists reveal Emma Frost is manipulating both sides — her grief over Cyclops' death drives her to extremism (#4-6). Medusa ultimately destroys the cloud herself. Inhumans Prime #1 sets up the Royals and Black Bolt solos.
connection_notes: Follows: Death of X, Uncanny Inhumans. Leads to: Royals, Black Bolt by Ahmed, X-Men Gold/Blue. Resolves the Inhuman/Mutant conflict.

title: X-Force by Benjamin Percy Vol. 1
synopsis: Krakoa's black ops intelligence agency is born in violence when anti-mutant extremists assassinate Professor Xavier on Krakoan soil in X-Force #1, shattering the illusion of safety. Xavier is resurrected via the Five's protocols, but the trauma reframes everything: Krakoa needs a CIA. Beast, Wolverine, Jean Grey, and Domino form X-Force under Beast's increasingly amoral leadership. Percy's run explores the dark underbelly of nation-building — what happens when a utopia must do ugly things to survive. Beast begins his transformation from beloved Avenger to Krakoa's most dangerous operative, authorizing black sites and preemptive strikes. Wolverine serves as the blunt instrument while Jean Grey provides the conscience. XENO, a human supremacist organization, provides the external threat. The series raises critical questions about surveillance states and the cost of security that echo throughout the Krakoan era.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: House of X / Powers of X. Parallel: all Dawn of X titles. Beast's moral descent here impacts every subsequent Krakoan title. Leads to: X-Force Vol. 2.

title: Marauders by Gerry Duggan Vol. 1
synopsis: Kate Pryde cannot walk through the Krakoan gates — the defining mystery of the early Krakoan era. Instead, she captains a ship with Storm, Iceman, Bishop, and Pyro, sailing the world to rescue mutants trapped in hostile nations. The Hellfire Trading Company, led by Emma Frost as White Queen and Sebastian Shaw as Black King, provides the economic framework for Krakoa's pharmaceutical trade with the human world. Shaw's machinations culminate in the murder of Kate Pryde (#6), testing the resurrection protocols in the most personal way possible when Kate initially cannot be resurrected. The geopolitics of mutant rescue missions in countries like Madripoor and anti-mutant Russia add real-world weight. Lockheed the dragon is delightful throughout. Emma Frost is at her scheming, fashionable best.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: House of X / Powers of X. Kate Pryde's death/resurrection impacts X of Swords. Shaw's treachery is a long-running thread. Parallel: X-Force, Excalibur.

title: Excalibur by Tini Howard Vol. 1
synopsis: Betsy Braddock takes up the mantle of Captain Britain after her brother Brian is corrupted by Morgan le Fay, connecting the mutant nation of Krakoa to the mystical realm of Otherworld. Howard weaves Arthurian mythology through the X-Men lens as Betsy, Rogue, Gambit, Rictor, Jubilee, and Apocalypse form a team operating at the intersection of magic and mutantkind. Apocalypse's presence is the key revelation: En Sabah Nur's interest in Otherworld connects to his original family, trapped in Amenth for millennia. The series establishes the crucial Krakoan-era rule that resurrection protocols do not work properly for mutants killed in Otherworld — their souls return scrambled. This single plot point becomes the linchpin of the X of Swords crossover. Rictor's earth-manipulation powers evolve through magical training. The Starlight Citadel, Captain Britain Corps, and the Otherworld gate network all become essential Krakoan infrastructure.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: House of X / Powers of X. Directly sets up X of Swords. Apocalypse's Otherworld connection is revealed here. Leads to: Excalibur Vol. 2, Knights of X.

title: Hellions by Zeb Wells: The Complete Collection
synopsis: The best ongoing title of the Krakoan era that nobody expected. Mister Sinister leads a team of Krakoa's most psychologically damaged and dangerous mutants — Havok, Psylocke (Kwannon), Wild Child, Nanny, Orphan-Maker, Empath, and Greycrow — on missions too dirty for X-Force and too chaotic for anyone else. Wells delivers pitch-black humor as Sinister treats the team as disposable pawns in his secret genetic experiments, dying and being resurrected with alarming frequency. Psylocke (Kwannon) emerges as the emotional core, struggling to protect her team from their own worst impulses and Sinister's manipulations. The series explores what rehabilitation looks like for mutants with histories of violence and abuse when death itself is no longer permanent. Orphan-Maker's armor conceals a terrifying omega-level threat. The Right organization returns. Sinister's genetic library subplot directly feeds into his long game revealed in Immortal X-Men. The finale is devastating and earned.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: House of X / Powers of X. Sinister's scheming here connects to Immortal X-Men and Sins of Sinister. Parallel: X-Force, X-Factor.

title: New Mutants by Ed Brisson & Vita Ayala Vol. 1
synopsis: The original New Mutants — Sunspot, Cannonball, Magik, Dani Moonstar, Wolfsbane, Karma, and others — navigate life in the Krakoan era. Brisson opens with a space adventure (#1-2) as the team heads to Shi'ar space to recruit mutants, bringing a lighthearted tone that contrasts with the political intrigue of other Krakoan titles. Vita Ayala's subsequent issues shift focus to life on the island, exploring what a young mutant's daily existence looks like in this new society. The Shadow King's influence creates tension. Cosmar, a young mutant whose appearance reflects her emotional state, becomes a compelling new character study in how Krakoan culture handles difference. The series provides essential ground-level perspective on Krakoa, showing the nation not through the Quiet Council's political lens but through the everyday experiences of its youngest citizens trying to find meaning beyond just survival.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: House of X / Powers of X. Parallel: Dawn of X titles. Character threads feed into X of Swords. Connects to classic New Mutants legacy.

title: S.W.O.R.D. by Al Ewing
synopsis: Abigail Brand transforms the Sentient World Observation and Response Department into Krakoa's space station, the Peak, establishing mutantkind as a galactic power. Ewing brings his cosmic sensibilities to the X-line as Brand assembles a team including Magneto, Cable, Frenzy, Fabian Cortez, Manifold, and Wiz-Kid to project Krakoan influence across the universe. The terraforming of Mars into the mutant world Arakko during the Hellfire Gala (#6) is a landmark moment — mutants claim an entire planet, declaring themselves a solar system-level civilization. Storm becomes Regent of Arakko. Brand's true loyalties become increasingly suspect as she plays every faction against each other. The series connects the Krakoan era to the broader Marvel cosmic tapestry, with the Shi'ar, Kree, Skrull, and other empires forced to reckon with mutantkind's sudden elevation to major galactic player. Ewing's trademark densely layered plotting is on full display.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: House of X / Powers of X, X of Swords. Mars terraforming is a pivotal Krakoan moment. Leads to: X-Men Red. Brand's betrayal plays out in Fall of X.

title: Way of X by Si Spurrier
issues_collected: Way of X #1-5, X-Men: The Onslaught Revelation #1
synopsis: Nightcrawler grapples with the philosophical and spiritual implications of Krakoan resurrection: if death has no meaning, what happens to the soul? Spurrier crafts a deeply theological exploration as Kurt Wagner attempts to build a mutant religion — a moral framework for a people who have transcended mortality. The Lost, a nihilistic faction of young mutants who throw themselves into deadly combat for sport because resurrection makes death meaningless, embody the crisis. Onslaught lurks in the psychic background, feeding on the spiritual void. Legion, Professor Xavier's reality-warping son, becomes Kurt's unlikely partner in building something meaningful. The climax in The Onslaught Revelation sees Nightcrawler defeat Onslaught by establishing the Spark, a Krakoan spiritual practice that gives purpose beyond mere survival. This is the most philosophically ambitious title of the Krakoan era and directly leads into Spurrier's Legion of X.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: House of X / Powers of X. Leads to: Legion of X. Nightcrawler's Spark becomes Krakoan institution. Parallel: Krakoan cultural titles.

title: Wolverine by Benjamin Percy Vol. 2
synopsis: Logan continues his dual role as X-Force operative and Krakoa's most dangerous lone wolf. Percy deepens the espionage thriller elements as Wolverine confronts Solem, a new rival with adamantium skin introduced during X of Swords, across issues #13-17 in a cat-and-mouse game that spans multiple continents. The CIA's anti-mutant operations intensify. Maverick returns, pulling Logan back into his Weapon X past. Logan's relationship with Jean Grey evolves under the Krakoan polyamorous norms, adding emotional complexity to a character traditionally defined by lonely brooding. Deadpool guest-stars in a standout two-parter. Percy excels at balancing Logan's berserker fury with quiet character moments, and Adam Kubert's art brings visceral intensity to the action sequences. The series consistently explores what a man built for violence does in a society that has theoretically transcended it.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Wolverine Percy Vol. 1 / Wolverine Percy Omnibus. Solem introduced in X of Swords. Parallel: X-Force. Connects to X Lives/X Deaths of Wolverine.

title: X-Men by Gerry Duggan Vol. 1
synopsis: Following Jonathan Hickman's departure from the X-line, Gerry Duggan takes the reins of the flagship X-Men title with a democratically elected team assembled during the first Hellfire Gala. The roster — Cyclops, Jean Grey, Wolverine, Synch, Sunfire, Polaris, and Rogue — is chosen by popular vote, reflecting Krakoa's evolving democratic institutions. The team establishes a Treehouse headquarters in Central Park, making the X-Men publicly visible in a way they haven't been since leaving the Xavier School. High Evolutionary launches an attack that tests the new team's cohesion. Doctor Stasis, a villain connected to Mister Sinister's genetic legacy, emerges as a recurring antagonist. Duggan balances superhero action with political dynamics, showing the X-Men simultaneously fighting cosmic threats and managing public relations. Larraz's art is stunning, bringing the same visual grandeur that made House of X so impactful.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: House of X / Powers of X, Hickman X-Men. Post-Hickman status quo. Leads to: X-Men Duggan Vol. 2, Hellfire Gala events. Parallel: all Krakoan titles.

title: Knights of X by Tini Howard
synopsis: Captain Britain (Betsy Braddock) assembles a quest team — Gambit, Rachel Summers, Rictor, Shatterstar, Bei the Blood Moon, and Meggan — to retrieve the Siege Perilous from Merlyn's forces in Otherworld. Following the events of X of Swords, the Starlight Citadel has fallen to Merlyn and his witch-breaker armies. Howard delivers an Arthurian fantasy quest filtered through the X-Men lens, with each knight facing trials that test their deepest insecurities. Gambit must confront his thieving nature. Rachel reckons with the hound conditioning from her Days of Future Past timeline. Rictor's magical evolution reaches new heights. The series expands Otherworld mythology and sets up the ongoing tension between Krakoa and Merlyn's regime that continues into the broader narrative. Bei the Blood Moon, Apocalypse's daughter-in-law from Arakko, is a standout addition to the X-family.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Excalibur by Howard, X of Swords. Continues Otherworld subplot. Parallel: Betsy Braddock Captain Britain thread.

title: Legion of X by Si Spurrier
synopsis: Nightcrawler's Spark — the spiritual practice he founded in Way of X — becomes an institution, and Kurt Wagner takes on the role of Krakoa's chief law enforcer and spiritual guide simultaneously. Legion (David Haller) provides the psychic muscle as the Altar, a pocket dimension within his mind, serves as Krakoa's courtroom and spiritual sanctuary. Spurrier continues his exploration of Krakoan philosophy: what does justice look like in a nation where death is not permanent? What crimes matter when murder can be undone? Doctor Nemesis, Pixie, Blindfold (resurrected), and Juggernaut (honorary mutant) fill out the cast. The Patchwork Man threatens the psychic plane. Mother Righteous, one of Sinister's clones, manipulates events from the shadows, collecting favors that feed into Sins of Sinister. The series is the rare X-book that prioritizes ideas over action, making it essential for readers invested in the Krakoan experiment's deeper implications.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Way of X. Mother Righteous connects to Immortal X-Men / Sins of Sinister. Parallel: Krakoan cultural/spiritual titles.

title: Sabretooth by Victor LaValle
synopsis: Victor Creed was the first mutant exiled to the Pit of Krakoa — a living prison beneath the island where the condemned exist in a state of psychic stasis, fully conscious but unable to move or act. Horror novelist Victor LaValle turns this into a genuinely unsettling exploration of confinement, rehabilitation, and whether someone like Sabretooth can ever change. In the Pit, Creed builds a psychic world from memories and encounters other exiled mutants: Madison Jeffries, Third Eye, Oya, and Nekra. Sabretooth & The Exiles continues as Creed escapes and leads his fellow prisoners on a journey through the multiverse, seeking freedom from Krakoan justice. LaValle's literary horror sensibilities elevate what could be a simple villain book into a meditation on punishment, redemption, and the limits of utopian justice. The Pit of Krakoa is the Krakoan era's most disturbing institution, and this series forces readers to confront it.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: House of X (Sabretooth exiled in issue #6). Explores Krakoan justice system. Parallel: Legion of X (different angle on Krakoan law).

title: X-Men Red by Al Ewing
synopsis: Storm rules as Regent of Arakko (formerly Mars), governing a planet of warrior mutants from a culture that prizes combat and strength above all. Ewing's masterwork of the Krakoan era explores what happens when pacifistic Krakoan ideals collide with Arakko's gladiatorial traditions. Magneto arrives on Arakko and finds purpose in building something new rather than fighting for what was. The Great Ring of Arakko — the planet's governing council — operates through ritual combat, and every political dispute is settled with fists. Sunspot serves as diplomat. Cable represents Krakoa's interests. Vulcan is barely contained. The Fisher King, a threat seeded from X of Swords, destabilizes the planet. Abigail Brand's long-simmering betrayal of mutantkind reaches its first stages. Storm's leadership — combining her innate compassion with an understanding of Arakkii warrior culture — is the finest character work she has received in decades. This is Al Ewing at his absolute best.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: S.W.O.R.D. by Ewing, X of Swords. Essential for Fall of X context. Storm and Magneto arcs peak here. Brand's betrayal leads to Fall of X.

title: Cable by Gerry Duggan
synopsis: Young Cable — the time-displaced teenage version who killed his older self in Extermination — adjusts to life on Krakoa with the irrepressible energy of a kid who has a giant techno-organic arm and access to future weapons. Duggan leans into the fun of a young Nathan Summers attending Krakoan parties, dating Esme Cuckoo, and butting heads with his parents Cyclops and Jean Grey while still dealing with cosmic-level threats. The Spaceknights of Galador threaten Earth. The Five Swords of the ancients must be recovered. Phil Noto's gorgeous watercolor-style art gives the series a distinctive visual identity that sets it apart from the grittier X-titles. Cable's youthful perspective on the Krakoan experiment — seeing it as simply the world he inherited rather than a revolutionary paradigm shift — provides refreshing contrast to the older characters' weight of history. The X of Swords tie-in issues (#6-8) are integral to that crossover.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: House of X / Powers of X. X of Swords tie-in issues #6-8. Parallel: Dawn of X and Reign of X titles.

title: X-Factor by Leah Williams
synopsis: When a mutant dies and needs resurrection, someone has to investigate the death. X-Factor serves as Krakoa's coroner and detective squad, led by Northstar and Polaris, with Prodigy, Eye-Boy, Daken, Prestige (Rachel Summers), and Aurora filling out the roster. Williams crafts a murder mystery procedural set against the Krakoan backdrop: if death is temporary, why does it still matter how someone died? The Wind Dancer investigation (#1-2) establishes the format. The Morrigan, a Celtic death goddess, threatens the resurrection process itself. Siryn's complicated relationship with death — she has died and been resurrected so many times — provides the emotional throughline. The Boneyard, X-Factor's headquarters, is a wonderfully macabre home base. The series is cancelled too early at #10, wrapping into the Trial of Magneto event, but Williams packs more character development and genuine emotional stakes into these issues than most runs twice the length.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: House of X / Powers of X. Explores resurrection mechanics. Leads to: Trial of Magneto. Parallel: Krakoan era procedural storytelling.

title: Trials of X Vol. 1
issues_collected: Reign of X selections: X-Men (2021) #1, X-Force #18, Marauders #19, Excalibur #19, Wolverine #11, New Mutants #16, Hellions #10, Way of X #1, X-Corp #1, S.W.O.R.D. #4, Cable #9
synopsis: The Krakoan publishing line transitions from the Dawn of X and Reign of X branding into the Trials of X era, collecting key issues from across the entire line in a single volume. This anthologized format provides a panoramic view of mutant civilization at its peak — before the cracks begin to show. Each title pushes its narrative forward: X-Force deals with escalating external threats, Marauders navigates the fallout of Kate Pryde's resurrection, Excalibur deepens the Otherworld connection, and the newly launched Way of X and X-Corp expand Krakoan institutions. The collection format mirrors the interconnected reading experience that the Krakoan era was designed to deliver, where developments in one title ripple across all others. For readers who prefer a curated cross-line sample over committing to every individual series, these volumes provide the essential narrative beats.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Dawn of X. Provides cross-line reading order. Parallel: all individual Krakoan titles.

title: Planet-Size X-Men
issues_collected: Planet-Size X-Men #1, X-Men: Hellfire Gala (2021) related issues
synopsis: The first annual Hellfire Gala — Krakoa's premiere social event where mutants demonstrate their power to the human world — culminates in the single most audacious act of the Krakoan era. Using an Omega-level mutant circuit combining the powers of Magneto, Exodus, Hope Summers, Elixir, Proteus, Vulcan, Iceman, and others, the X-Men terraform Mars into the mutant planet Arakko in a matter of hours. Pepe Larraz's double-page spread of the terraforming is one of the most stunning images in modern Marvel history. Storm is named Regent of Arakko. The Arakkii mutants — the descendants of Apocalypse's original people, trapped in the demon dimension of Amenth for millennia and freed during X of Swords — now have their own world. The political implications are staggering: mutantkind has gone from a persecuted minority to a two-planet civilization overnight. The galaxy takes notice. The Avengers take notice. Everything changes.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: X of Swords, S.W.O.R.D. Directly sets up X-Men Red. Storm's Arakko regency begins here. One of the most important single issues of the Krakoan era.

title: Inferno by Jonathan Hickman
synopsis: Jonathan Hickman's true finale to his X-Men saga — the story he was always building toward before restructuring his plans. Moira MacTaggert, whose reincarnating power was the foundation of the entire Krakoan era, is exposed. Mystique, who has been demanding Moira's resurrection since House of X #1, finally discovers that Moira is alive and that Xavier and Magneto have been lying to the Quiet Council the entire time. Mystique's vengeance is devastating: she and Destiny strip Moira of her mutant power using a Forgebreaker weapon, making Moira permanently human. Without her reincarnation ability, Moira cannot reset the timeline if things go wrong — every choice from this point is final. The political fallout reshapes the Quiet Council as Destiny and Mystique take seats of power. Emma Frost consolidates influence. Hickman ties off his personal narrative threads while leaving the broader Krakoan experiment for Gillen, Ewing, and Duggan to conclude. This is where Hickman intended to end, and it shows in every perfectly calibrated panel.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: House of X / Powers of X. Hickman's personal conclusion. Moira's depowering changes everything. Leads to: Immortal X-Men, Sins of Sinister. Essential.

title: A.X.E.: Judgment Day Companion
issues_collected: A.X.E.: Judgment Day tie-ins — X-Men Red #5-7, Immortal X-Men #5-7, Avengers #60, Death to the Mutants #1-3, Starfox #1
synopsis: The essential tie-in issues that deepen the A.X.E.: Judgment Day event beyond the core miniseries. On Arakko, Al Ewing's X-Men Red chapters show Magneto's death at the hands of Uranos the Undying during the Eternal's devastating eight-minute assault on the mutant planet — one of the most brutal sequences in recent Marvel history. One hundred Arakkii mutants die in eight minutes. Magneto's final stand is heroic and heartbreaking. Kieron Gillen's Immortal X-Men tie-ins show the Quiet Council's response as the Celestial Progenitor judges all of humanity, mutant and otherwise. Each individual faces personal judgment: pass or fail, worthy or wanting. Death to the Mutants follows the Eternal faction determined to fulfill their cosmic programming regardless of moral objections. The Starfox one-shot provides crucial Eternal mythology. These tie-ins contain some of the strongest writing of the entire event.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: A.X.E. Judgment Day core series. Magneto's death here is critical. Enhances main event significantly. Parallel: Judgment Day main series.

title: X-Men Red by Al Ewing Vol. 2
synopsis: Arakko reels from Uranos's eight-minute genocide during Judgment Day. Storm leads the shattered planet's recovery while dealing with the political fallout of Magneto's death. Ewing shifts the series into its post-Judgment Day phase as Abigail Brand's treachery escalates — she has been playing every faction against each other, building toward a personal power grab that will have catastrophic consequences during Fall of X. Genesis (the ancient mutant warrior, Apocalypse's wife) returns from Amenth with imperial ambitions. Vulcan, barely stable at the best of times, becomes even more unpredictable. The Great Ring of Arakko undergoes power shifts as war-culture clashes with mourning. Storm's leadership is tested to its absolute limits as she must rebuild a civilization while surrounded by betrayal. Ewing writes Storm as the most powerful and complex she has ever been — regent, goddess, weather witch, and reluctant queen.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: X-Men Red Vol. 1, A.X.E. Judgment Day. Brand's betrayal escalates. Storm's arc culminates. Leads to: Fall of X.

title: Wolverine by Saladin Ahmed Vol. 1
synopsis: As the Krakoan era enters its twilight, Wolverine operates in the chaos of the Fall of X, hunted by Orchis and cut off from the resurrection protocols that made death temporary. Ahmed strips Logan back to his essentials: a man alone with claws and fury, fighting to protect those who can't protect themselves. Without Krakoa's safety net, every wound matters again. Logan confronts Cyber in a brutal rematch that tests his healing factor to its limits. A new human supremacist group, armed with stolen Orchis technology, targets mutant refugees. Ahmed brings the same literary sensibility that elevated his Miles Morales and Black Bolt runs, grounding Logan's violence in emotional specificity. The series provides a ground-level view of the Fall of X's human cost, following mutant refugees whose stories rarely make the flagship titles.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Fall of X status quo. Ground-level perspective on Fall of X. Connects to: broader Wolverine continuity.

title: Venom War
synopsis: Eddie Brock and his son Dylan Brock wage war over the symbiote legacy in a conflict that tears the Venom mythos apart and rebuilds it. Following Donny Cates's redefinition of symbiote lore through the King in Black event, Ewing takes the Brock family drama to its breaking point. Eddie, transformed by his time as the King in Black, has become something beyond human, while Dylan struggles with the symbiote's influence on his developing identity. Multiple symbiotes choose sides. Toxin, Sleeper, and other spawn of the Venom lineage are drawn into the conflict. Anti-Venom resurfaces. The war reshapes the symbiote hierarchy, establishing new rules for how the alien organisms interact with human hosts. Ewing's trademark layered plotting connects the symbiote mythology to the broader Marvel cosmic landscape, with implications for the Klyntar homeworld and the universal balance of power.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Venom by Cates, King in Black. Reshapes symbiote status quo. Parallel: broader 2024 Marvel events.

title: Amazing Spider-Man: Gang War
issues_collected: Amazing Spider-Man: Gang War #1-5, Amazing Spider-Man (2022) #40-43
synopsis: New York City's criminal underworld erupts as every major crime boss makes a simultaneous play for control of the city's streets. The Kingpin's absence creates a power vacuum that Tombstone, Hammerhead, Madame Masque, Mister Negative, the Rose, and others rush to fill. Spider-Man is caught in the crossfire of a multi-front mob war that makes the city more dangerous than it has been since the gang wars of the 1990s. Mayor Luke Cage mobilizes NYC's street-level heroes — Miles Morales, She-Hulk, White Tiger, Shang-Chi — in a coordinated response. The event forces Peter Parker to confront how much of his rogues gallery's power he has inadvertently enabled by never solving the systemic problems. Wells delivers kinetic action across multiple fronts while John Romita Jr.'s angular, kinetic art perfectly suits the gritty street-level violence.
connection_notes: Parallel: ASM by Zeb Wells ongoing. Street-level Spider-Man event. Connects to broader NYC crime landscape in Daredevil.

title: Ultimate Black Panther Vol. 1
synopsis: In Jonathan Hickman's relaunched Ultimate Universe, Wakanda exists under the shadow of the Maker's global manipulation. T'Challa must navigate a world where the familiar power structures have been secretly controlled by an evil Reed Richards for decades. Hill reimagines Wakanda's mythology from the ground up: the Black Panther mantle carries different weight in a world where the superhero era was suppressed before it could begin. Moon Knight appears as an unlikely Wakandan ally. Killmonger's role is completely reinvented. Storm exists in this universe but under vastly different circumstances than her 616 counterpart. The vibranium politics, the Panther God, and the Dora Milaje are all present but reconfigured for this fresh continuity. Caselli's art brings a cinematic scope that suits the geopolitical thriller tone. The series expands the new Ultimate Universe beyond New York, proving the Maker's influence extends to every corner of the globe.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Ultimate Invasion. Parallel: Ultimate Spider-Man, Ultimate X-Men. Expands new Ultimate Universe. Part of the Ultimate line.

title: Ultimate X-Men Vol. 1
synopsis: Peach Momoko delivers the most visually distinctive and narratively unconventional X-Men book in years. Set in the new Ultimate Universe, this version of the X-Men draws heavily from Japanese mythology and horror, following Hisako Ichiki (Armor) and a cast of young mutants discovering their powers in a world where the concept of 'mutant' does not yet exist as a cultural framework. Without Xavier, without the school, without the dream — what does it mean to be a mutant when there is no community to belong to? Momoko's watercolor art creates an ethereal, dreamlike atmosphere completely unlike any other Marvel book. The storytelling is nonlinear and impressionistic, prioritizing emotional truth over plot mechanics. Shadow King appears as a genuine horror entity. The series redefines what an X-Men comic can be and look like, proving the concept transcends its familiar American superhero framework.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Ultimate Invasion. Standalone within Ultimate Universe. Parallel: Ultimate Spider-Man, Ultimate Black Panther. Radically different X-Men approach.

title: Ultimate Spider-Man Vol. 3
synopsis: Peter Parker's war against the Maker's invisible empire escalates as the Ultimate Universe's true power structures begin to crack. Hickman deepens the central thesis: what happens when Spider-Man gets to grow up, have a family, and still choose to fight? The married Peter and MJ dynamic — denied in 616 since One More Day — provides the emotional bedrock. The Green Goblin, reimagined as a figure connected to the Maker's experiments rather than OsCorp industrial accidents, presents a threat that strikes at Peter's family directly. Tony Stark and other nascent heroes begin to organize. Checchetto's art remains immaculate, bringing a European graphic novel sensibility to superhero storytelling. The series continues to be one of Marvel's best-selling and most critically acclaimed books, proving that fans hunger for a Spider-Man allowed to mature and a continuity unburdened by sixty years of accumulated contradictions.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Ultimate Spider-Man Vols. 1-2. Ongoing. Parallel: all Ultimate Universe titles. The Maker's empire crumbles.

title: Fantastic Four by Ryan North Vol. 2
synopsis: Ryan North continues his critically acclaimed and deeply charming Fantastic Four run, bringing his trademark wit and scientific rigor to Marvel's First Family. Each issue operates as a standalone adventure driven by the FF using actual science to solve impossible problems — Reed's genius is shown through process, not just proclamation. Sue faces an opponent who can only be defeated through creative use of her force fields (#8). Johnny must outwit a threat without his flame (#9). Ben Grimm gets a solo spotlight exploring what it means to be the strongest and most vulnerable member of the team simultaneously (#10). The Impossible Man returns in a meta-textual issue (#11) that plays with comic book conventions. North's comedic sensibility never undermines the emotional stakes; instead, the humor makes the family dynamics feel more authentic. Iban Coello's clean, expressive art perfectly complements the scripts.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: FF by Ryan North Vol. 1. Ongoing. Self-contained stories within broader continuity. Leads to: continued Ryan North FF.

title: Amazing Spider-Man by Zeb Wells Vol. 2
synopsis: Wells deepens the mystery of what Peter Parker did during the six-month gap that alienated him from everyone in his life. The Hobgoblin resurfaces with new power. Norman Osborn, rehabilitated after his time as the Gold Goblin, maintains his fragile sanity while mentoring Peter in an uncomfortable role reversal. The relationship between Peter and Mary Jane remains strained, with the revelation that MJ spent time in another dimension raising two children adding layers of complicated emotion. Gang War builds in the background as New York's criminal landscape shifts. Ms. Marvel makes guest appearances that tie into her broader Marvel role. Wells writes Peter at his most isolated and self-loathing, which is narratively intentional but polarized readers who prefer a more triumphant Spider-Man. The art alternates between Romita Jr.'s angular kineticism and McGuinness's rounder, more dynamic style.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: ASM by Zeb Wells Vol. 1. Leads to: Gang War, ASM ongoing. Parallel: broader Spider-Man line.

title: Immortal Thor by Al Ewing Vol. 1
synopsis: Al Ewing brings his cosmic mythology sensibilities to the God of Thunder, reframing Thor not as a superhero who happens to be a god but as a mythological force given story-shape by human belief. Toranos, the Elder God of storms who existed before Odin, before Asgard, before the concept of 'Thor' itself, awakens and claims to be the original thunder — making Thor a mere echo. Ewing draws on Norse, Greek, and Hindu storm mythology to explore what it means to be a god in a universe of gods. Loki serves as narrator, unreliable as always. Enchantress returns with genuine menace. The Utgard-Loki, a being from the outermost realm of Norse cosmology, threatens to unmake reality's narrative structure. Ewing writes with literary density, layering mythological references and metaliterary commentary without sacrificing superhero spectacle. Martin Coccolo's art balances divine grandeur with intimate character moments.
connection_notes: Standalone but enriched by prior Thor mythology. Parallel: broader Ewing Marvel cosmic work (Defenders, Ultimates). Leads to: continued Immortal Thor.

title: Avengers by Jed MacKay Vol. 2
synopsis: MacKay's Avengers roster — Captain America (Sam Wilson), Iron Man, Thor, Captain Marvel, Scarlet Witch, Vision, and Black Panther — faces escalating threats as the team finds its rhythm. The Twilight Court, an ancient organization that has manipulated human civilization from the shadows, emerges as the primary antagonist. MacKay excels at team dynamics, giving each member distinct voices and interpersonal tensions that feel organic rather than manufactured. Sam Wilson's Captain America leads with a different style than Steve Rogers — more collaborative, more communicative, occasionally more uncertain. The Vision and Scarlet Witch relationship, complicated by their history, provides emotional undertow. Blood Hunt tie-in issues force the Avengers to confront the global vampire invasion, directly setting up Doom's rise. MacKay writes efficient, propulsive superhero storytelling that respects the team's legacy while pushing forward.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Avengers by MacKay Vol. 1. Blood Hunt tie-ins. Leads to: One World Under Doom tie-ins.

title: Scarlet Witch by Steve Orlando Vol. 2
synopsis: Wanda Maximoff continues her redemptive arc following her role in House of M, operating from the Emporium — a magical shop where desperate people bring impossible problems. Orlando's second volume deepens Wanda's role as Marvel's premier magic user, positioning her alongside Doctor Strange as a protector of the mystical realm. With Strange dead following Blood Hunt, Wanda is now the most powerful sorcerer on Earth who is not Doctor Doom. She investigates magical disturbances caused by the power vacuum Strange's death created. The Darkhold's influence resurfaces. Agatha Harkness, Wanda's mentor, returns with ambiguous motives. Orlando writes Wanda with agency and self-awareness — she knows her history, acknowledges her mistakes, and actively works to be better. Pichelli's art is gorgeous, bringing elegance to the magical set pieces that define the series' visual identity.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Scarlet Witch by Orlando Vol. 1. Doctor Strange's death in Blood Hunt impacts her role. Parallel: mystical Marvel corner. Doom as Sorcerer Supreme creates tension.

title: Daredevil by Saladin Ahmed Vol. 1
synopsis: Matt Murdock and Elektra Natchios share the Daredevil mantle in a new era that builds on Chip Zdarsky's landmark run. Ahmed inherits a Matt Murdock who has been through hell — prison, near-death, the leadership of the Hand — and must find a new reason to fight for Hell's Kitchen. The neighborhood itself is changing as post-Blood Hunt New York rebuilds. A new crime syndicate, the Seventh Circle, fills the vacuum left by the Kingpin's absence and Gang War's fallout. Ahmed brings the same literary depth that characterized his Miles Morales and Black Bolt work, grounding Matt's enhanced senses in visceral, poetic description. Elektra's parallel Daredevil operation creates natural narrative tension and partnership dynamics. The series honors the legacy of Miller, Bendis, Brubaker, Waid, and Zdarsky while carving a distinct identity. Kuder's art is kinetic and shadow-drenched, perfect for the character.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Daredevil by Zdarsky. Post-Blood Hunt, post-Gang War status quo. Parallel: street-level Marvel titles.

title: Wolverine: Revenge
synopsis: Jonathan Hickman and Greg Capullo team up for a prestige Wolverine story set outside the ongoing continuity. Logan is poisoned, his healing factor failing, and he has twenty-four hours to hunt down the five people who betrayed him — Sabretooth, Omega Red, Deadpool, Mystique, and one devastating surprise reveal. Capullo, best known for his decade-long Batman collaboration with Scott Snyder, brings a visceral, hyper-detailed art style that makes every claw slash and blood splatter feel impactful. Hickman strips the story to its primal core: revenge, mortality, and whether a man who has lived for centuries can accept death. The countdown structure creates relentless momentum. Each confrontation reveals a piece of the puzzle — who poisoned Logan and why. The oversized hardcover format allows Capullo's art to breathe on the page. This is a standalone story designed to be the definitive 'one last mission' Wolverine narrative.
connection_notes: Standalone prestige miniseries. No continuity prerequisites. Hickman/Capullo collaboration event.

title: Uncanny X-Men by Gerry Duggan Vol. 1
synopsis: The Uncanny X-Men title relaunches as part of the From the Ashes initiative following the end of the Krakoan era. Rogue leads a team including Gambit, Wolverine (Laura Kinney), Nightcrawler, Jubilee, and Havok in a return to the X-Men's classic mission — protecting a world that hates and fears them. Without Krakoan infrastructure, without resurrection protocols, without a nation, the X-Men must rebuild from the ground up. Duggan, who wrote the flagship X-Men title through the latter Krakoan era, understands these characters deeply and writes their post-Krakoa trauma with specificity. What do you do when the utopia you built is gone? Rogue's leadership style is direct, compassionate, and fierce. A new anti-mutant political movement, emboldened by Krakoa's fall, represents the eternal cycle of human bigotry that the X-Men exist to fight.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Rise of the Powers of X (end of Krakoa). From the Ashes relaunch title. Parallel: X-Men From the Ashes, Exceptional X-Men, NYX.

title: Exceptional X-Men Vol. 1
synopsis: Emma Frost establishes a new school for young mutants in Chicago, returning to the education mission that defined the X-Men's original purpose. Ewing, an accomplished author and educator, brings genuine understanding of young people's voices to a cast of new mutant students navigating powers, identity, and a world that just watched the Krakoan dream collapse. Emma serves as headmistress and protector, channeling her White Queen ruthlessness into maternal fierce protectiveness. The school operates without Xavier's ideology or Krakoa's infrastructure — just Emma's wealth, her telepathy, and her determination that these children will not suffer as she did. Bronze, Axo, and other new student characters feel authentic rather than tokenistic. The anti-mutant backlash following Krakoa's fall creates immediate external danger. Ewing writes Emma with the sharp wit and hidden vulnerability that has made her one of Marvel's most compelling characters over the past two decades.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: End of Krakoa era. From the Ashes relaunch. Emma Frost-focused. Parallel: Uncanny X-Men, NYX, X-Men.

title: Phoenix by Stephanie Phillips
synopsis: Jean Grey, fully bonded with the Phoenix Force, operates as a cosmic protector in the aftermath of Krakoa's fall. Phillips takes Jean beyond Earth, exploring the Phoenix Force's role in the universal ecology — it is not just a weapon or a curse but a fundamental cosmic constant, the force of life, death, and rebirth that maintains universal balance. Jean confronts threats on a galactic scale while processing the grief of losing Krakoa and the complicated feelings about what the mutant nation meant and what it cost. The Shi'ar, who worship the Phoenix as a god, react to Jean's return to cosmic prominence with religious fervor and political calculation. The Starjammers appear. The series redefines Jean Grey as more than 'the woman who dies,' reclaiming the Phoenix as empowering rather than tragic. Miracolo's art renders cosmic vistas with appropriate grandeur.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Rise of the Powers of X, Jean Grey's Phoenix bonding. Cosmic scope. Parallel: From the Ashes titles.

title: Doctor Doom by Rodwell Frietas
synopsis: Doctor Doom's 2024 solo series bridges Blood Hunt and One World Under Doom, charting Victor Von Doom's transformation from Latverian monarch to Sorcerer Supreme to world conqueror. After claiming the title of Sorcerer Supreme during Blood Hunt — filling the void left by Doctor Strange's death — Doom possesses both supreme magical authority and his existing technological mastery. The series shows Doom consolidating power, eliminating rivals, and building the infrastructure for global conquest. Valeria Richards, Doom's goddaughter, serves as the moral counterpoint, challenging her Uncle Doom's conviction that only he can save humanity. The Latverian people, simultaneously liberated and oppressed by their monarch, provide a microcosm for the global dilemma to come. The series is essential reading between Blood Hunt and One World Under Doom, showing the meticulous planning behind what could appear to be opportunistic conquest.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Blood Hunt. Bridges Blood Hunt to One World Under Doom. Doom becomes Sorcerer Supreme. Essential for Doom arc understanding.

title: Blood Hunt Companion
issues_collected: Blood Hunt: Red Band #1-5, Blood Hunt tie-in selections from Avengers, X-Men, Dracula
synopsis: The essential tie-in collection for Blood Hunt expands the scope of the vampire invasion beyond the core miniseries. The Red Band issues provide the uncensored, horror-forward version of key moments — Doctor Strange's death is rendered in graphic detail, and the vampire transformation of key characters hits harder without editorial restraint. Avengers tie-ins show the team's desperate defense of New York City as daylight disappears globally. The Dracula spotlight reveals the Lord of Vampires' complex response to Blade's corruption — Dracula views the invasion as a perversion of vampire culture, not its fulfillment. X-Men tie-in issues depict the mutant response during the Fall of X, when scattered mutant cells must fight vampires without their usual resources. The collection provides crucial context for Doom's power play, showing how he positioned himself as humanity's savior during the crisis.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: Blood Hunt core series. Enhances main event. Doctor Strange death details. Leads to: One World Under Doom.

title: Spider-Man: Reign 2
synopsis: Kaare Andrews returns to his divisive Dark Knight Returns-inspired Spider-Man future for a sequel that expands the dystopian vision. An elderly Peter Parker, long retired from the webs, must confront a world that moved on without Spider-Man — and the consequences of his absence. Miles Morales, now middle-aged, has carried the Spider-Man legacy in Peter's place but faces his own crisis of purpose. Andrews' painterly art creates a bleak, atmospheric New York that feels both alien and heartbreakingly recognizable. The Sinister Six's legacy haunts the narrative. May Parker, Peter's daughter, inherits her father's powers and his impossible choice: save the people you love or save everyone else. The series is uncompromising in its vision — this is not a feel-good Spider-Man story but a meditation on aging, legacy, and whether one person's sacrifice can ever truly be enough. Not canonical to 616 continuity.
connection_notes: Standalone alternate future. Sequel to Spider-Man: Reign (2006). No continuity prerequisites. Prestige project.

title: Captain America (2025) Vol. 1
synopsis: Steve Rogers carries the shield in a post-One World Under Doom America that is fundamentally changed. Doom's brief global rule proved that a single authority could solve problems democracy cannot — and many Americans, having tasted a world without poverty and disease, are not grateful to have their messy freedom back. Rogers confronts a philosophical crisis more challenging than any supervillain: how do you defend freedom when people have legitimate reasons to question its value? Straczynski, returning to Marvel after years away, brings the same grounded, humanistic approach that defined his ASM run. Jesus Saiz's photorealistic art grounds every scene in tangible reality. New Hydra factions exploit the post-Doom political confusion. The Serpent Society returns with updated ideology. Sam Wilson, still active as a hero, provides partnership and philosophical counterbalance. The series asks whether Captain America's ideals are timeless or nostalgic.
connection_notes: Prerequisite: One World Under Doom aftermath. Post-Doom status quo. Parallel: current Avengers titles. Leads to: Armageddon.

title: Iron Man (2025) Vol. 1
synopsis: Tony Stark reckons with the aftermath of a world where Doom proved that technology and authoritarianism could solve problems Stark's inventions never could. Ackerman, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist covering national security, brings uncommon geopolitical literacy to Stark's story. Iron Man's technology, once the cutting edge, now exists in a world that briefly operated under Doom-level tech — and the arms race that follows is terrifying. Stark Industries faces hostile takeover attempts from corporations that reverse-engineered Doom-tech. A new Mandarin, wielding rings upgraded with Doom's magical-technological fusion, presents the nightmare scenario of Stark's two greatest weaknesses combined. Tony's sobriety is tested. Rhodey provides grounding. Ohta's mechanical design work brings fresh visual identity to the armor. The series explores the military-industrial complex with more nuance than Iron Man has managed in years.
connection_notes: Post-One World Under Doom. Doom-tech proliferation is the core threat. Parallel: Avengers, Captain America ongoing titles.

title: Thor (2025) Vol. 1
synopsis: Thor Odinson navigates the aftermath of One World Under Doom in Asgard and on Earth. Doom's brief global rule demonstrated that a mortal could achieve what the gods would not — solving human suffering through force — and the theological implications shake Asgardian cosmology. Kelly and Lanzing, who proved their cosmic bonafides on Captain America: Sentinel of Liberty and Guardians of the Galaxy, bring a mythic sensibility to Thor's dual role as Avenger and All-Father. A threat emerges from the World Tree itself, something that predates the current cycle of Ragnarok and renewal. Loki's allegiances are, as always, in question. Sif serves as Thor's primary ally and conscience. The Enchantress returns with a scheme that threatens the fabric of Yggdrasil. The series balances the intimate (Thor's identity as a god in a world that briefly had a mortal one) with the cosmic (existential threats to the Nine Realms).
connection_notes: Post-One World Under Doom. Connects to broader Asgardian mythology. Parallel: Immortal Thor by Ewing precedes this.

title: Hulk (2025) Vol. 1
synopsis: Bruce Banner and the Hulk continue their eternal negotiation in the aftermath of One World Under Doom. Phillip Kennedy Johnson, who proved his ability to write the gamma corner of Marvel with his Incredible Hulk run, takes the character into new territory as the post-Doom world grapples with what happens when Banner-level scientific genius is no longer the most dangerous thing on the planet. The gamma mutate community — She-Hulk, Red Hulk, Skaar, and others — faces a new threat as someone is systematically hunting and depowering gamma-powered beings. Banner investigates while managing the Hulk's response to a world that briefly lived under imposed peace. Nic Klein's expansive art, which brought epic scope to Jason Aaron's Thor, renders Hulk's destruction with appropriate devastation. The psychological interplay between Banner and Hulk, refined by decades of writers, reaches a new equilibrium as both personalities face the possibility that they are obsolete.
connection_notes: Post-One World Under Doom. Gamma family title. Parallel: Avengers, broader Marvel landscape.

title: Mystique by Declan Shalvey
